# King Arthur

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For other uses, see [King Arthur
(disambiguation)](/wiki/King_Arthur_\(disambiguation\) "King Arthur
\(disambiguation\)").

"Arthur Pendragon" redirects here. For other uses, see [Arthur Pendragon
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Arthur_Pendragon_\(disambiguation\) "Arthur Pendragon
\(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Arth_tapestry2.jpg/220px-
Arth_tapestry2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Arth_tapestry2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Arth_tapestry2.jpg "Enlarge")

Tapestry showing Arthur as one of the [Nine Worthies](/wiki/Nine_Worthies
"Nine Worthies"), wearing a [coat of arms](/wiki/Coat_of_arms "Coat of arms")
often attributed to him[1] (c. 1385)

**King Arthur** is a legendary [British](/wiki/Celtic_Britons "Celtic
Britons") leader who, according to medieval histories and
[romances](/wiki/Romance_\(heroic_literature\) "Romance \(heroic
literature\)"), led the defence of Britain against [Saxon](/wiki/Saxon
"Saxon") invaders in the late 5th and early 6th centuries AD. The details of
Arthur's story are mainly composed of [folklore](/wiki/Folklore "Folklore")
and literary invention, and his historical existence is debated and disputed
by modern historians.[2] The sparse historical background of Arthur is gleaned
from various sources, including the _[Annales Cambriae](/wiki/Annales_Cambriae
"Annales Cambriae")_ , the _[Historia Brittonum](/wiki/Historia_Brittonum
"Historia Brittonum")_ , and the writings of [Gildas](/wiki/Gildas "Gildas").
Arthur's name also occurs in early poetic sources such as _[Y
Gododdin](/wiki/Y_Gododdin "Y Gododdin")_.[3]

Arthur is a central figure in the legends making up the [Matter of
Britain](/wiki/Matter_of_Britain "Matter of Britain"). The legendary Arthur
developed as a figure of international interest largely through the popularity
of [Geoffrey of Monmouth](/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth "Geoffrey of Monmouth")'s
fanciful and imaginative 12th-century _[Historia Regum
Britanniae](/wiki/Historia_Regum_Britanniae "Historia Regum Britanniae")_
(_History of the Kings of Britain_).[4] In some [Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_people
"Welsh people") and [Breton](/wiki/Breton_people "Breton people") tales and
poems that date from before this work, Arthur appears either as a great
warrior defending Britain from human and supernatural enemies or as a magical
figure of folklore, sometimes associated with the Welsh
[Otherworld](/wiki/Otherworld "Otherworld"), [Annwn](/wiki/Annwn "Annwn").[5]
How much of Geoffrey's _Historia_ (completed in 1138) was adapted from such
earlier sources, rather than invented by Geoffrey himself, is unknown.

Although the themes, events and characters of the Arthurian legend varied
widely from text to text, and there is no one canonical version; Geoffrey's
[version of events](/wiki/King_Arthur#Geoffrey_of_Monmouth "King Arthur")
often served as the starting point for later stories. Geoffrey depicted Arthur
as a king of Britain who defeated the Saxons and established an empire over
[Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain"), [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland
"Ireland"), [Iceland](/wiki/Iceland "Iceland"), [Norway](/wiki/Norway
"Norway") and [Gaul](/wiki/Gaul "Gaul"). Many elements and incidents that are
now an integral part of the Arthurian story appear in Geoffrey's _Historia_ ,
including Arthur's father [Uther Pendragon](/wiki/Uther_Pendragon "Uther
Pendragon"), the wizard [Merlin](/wiki/Merlin "Merlin"), Arthur's wife
[Guinevere](/wiki/Guinevere "Guinevere"), the sword
[Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur"), Arthur's conception at
[Tintagel](/wiki/Tintagel_Castle "Tintagel Castle"), his final battle against
[Mordred](/wiki/Mordred "Mordred") at [Camlann](/wiki/Camlann "Camlann"), and
final rest in [Avalon](/wiki/Avalon "Avalon"). The 12th-century French writer
[Chrétien de Troyes](/wiki/Chr%C3%A9tien_de_Troyes "Chrétien de Troyes"), who
added [Lancelot](/wiki/Lancelot "Lancelot") and the [Holy
Grail](/wiki/Holy_Grail "Holy Grail") to the story, began the genre of
Arthurian romance that became a significant strand of [medieval
literature](/wiki/Medieval_literature "Medieval literature"). In these French
stories, the narrative focus often shifts from King Arthur himself to other
characters, such as various [Knights of the Round Table](/wiki/Round_Table
"Round Table"). Arthurian literature thrived during the Middle Ages but waned
in the centuries that followed until it experienced a major resurgence in the
19th century. In the 21st century, the legend lives on, not only in literature
but also in adaptations for theatre, film, television, comics and other media.

## Debated historicity

Main article: [Historicity of King Arthur](/wiki/Historicity_of_King_Arthur
"Historicity of King Arthur")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Innsbruck_1_262.jpg/220px-
Innsbruck_1_262.jpg)](/wiki/File:Innsbruck_1_262.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Innsbruck_1_262.jpg "Enlarge")

Statue of King Arthur at the [Hofkirche](/wiki/Hofkirche,_Innsbruck
"Hofkirche, Innsbruck") in [Innsbruck](/wiki/Innsbruck "Innsbruck"), designed
by [Albrecht Dürer](/wiki/Albrecht_D%C3%BCrer "Albrecht Dürer") and cast by
[Peter Vischer the Elder](/wiki/Peter_Vischer_the_Elder "Peter Vischer the
Elder") (1520s)[6]

The [historical basis](/wiki/Historicity "Historicity") for the King Arthur
legend has long been debated by scholars. One [school of
thought](/wiki/School_of_thought "School of thought"), citing entries in the
_[Historia Brittonum](/wiki/Historia_Brittonum "Historia Brittonum")_
(_History of the Britons_) and _[Annales Cambriae](/wiki/Annales_Cambriae
"Annales Cambriae")_ (_Welsh Annals_), sees Arthur as a genuine historical
figure, a [Romano-British](/wiki/Romano-British "Romano-British") leader who
fought against the invading [Anglo-Saxons](/wiki/Anglo-Saxons "Anglo-Saxons")
some time in the late 5th to early 6th century. The _Historia Brittonum_ , a
9th-century [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") historical compilation attributed in
some late manuscripts to a Welsh cleric called [Nennius](/wiki/Nennius
"Nennius"), contains the first datable mention of King Arthur, listing twelve
battles that Arthur fought. These culminate in the [Battle of
Badon](/wiki/Battle_of_Badon "Battle of Badon"), where he is said to have
single-handedly killed 960 men. Recent studies, however, question the
reliability of the _Historia Brittonum_.[7]

The other text that seems to support the case for Arthur's historical
existence is the 10th-century _Annales Cambriae_ , which also link Arthur with
the Battle of Badon. The _Annales_ date this battle to 516–518, and also
mention the [Battle of Camlann](/wiki/Battle_of_Camlann "Battle of Camlann"),
in which Arthur and [Medraut](/wiki/Mordred "Mordred") (Mordred) were both
killed, dated to 537–539. These details have often been used to bolster
confidence in the _Historia_ 's account and to confirm that Arthur really did
fight at Badon. Problems have been identified, however, with using this source
to support the _Historia Brittonum '_s account. The latest research shows that
the _Annales Cambriae_ was based on a chronicle begun in the late 8th century
in [Wales](/wiki/Wales "Wales"). Additionally, the complex textual history of
the _Annales Cambriae_ precludes any certainty that the Arthurian annals were
added to it even that early. They were more likely added at some point in the
10th century and may never have existed in any earlier set of annals. The
Badon entry probably derived from the _Historia Brittonum_.[8]

This lack of convincing early evidence is the reason many recent historians
exclude Arthur from their accounts of [sub-Roman Britain](/wiki/Sub-
Roman_Britain "Sub-Roman Britain"). In the view of historian [Thomas Charles-
Edwards](/wiki/Thomas_Charles-Edwards "Thomas Charles-Edwards"), "at this
stage of the enquiry, one can only say that there may well have been an
historical Arthur [but ...] the historian can as yet say nothing of value
about him".[9] These modern admissions of ignorance are a relatively recent
trend; earlier generations of historians were less sceptical. The historian
[John Morris](/wiki/John_Morris_\(historian\) "John Morris \(historian\)")
made the putative reign of Arthur the organising principle of his history of
sub-Roman Britain and [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"), _The Age of Arthur_
(1973). Even so, he found little to say about a historical Arthur.[10]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/AC.jpeg/200px-
AC.jpeg)](/wiki/File:AC.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:AC.jpeg "Enlarge")

The 10th-century _[Annales Cambriae](/wiki/Annales_Cambriae "Annales
Cambriae")_ (from a copy c. 1100)

Partly in reaction to such theories, another school of thought emerged which
argued that Arthur had no historical existence at all. Morris's _Age of
Arthur_ prompted the archaeologist [Nowell Myres](/wiki/Nowell_Myres "Nowell
Myres") to observe that "no figure on the borderline of history and mythology
has wasted more of the historian's time".[11] [Gildas](/wiki/Gildas "Gildas")'
6th-century polemic _[De Excidio et Conquestu
Britanniae](/wiki/De_Excidio_et_Conquestu_Britanniae "De Excidio et Conquestu
Britanniae")_ (_On the Ruin and Conquest of Britain_), written within living
memory of Badon, mentions the battle but does not mention Arthur.[12] Arthur
is not mentioned in the _[Anglo-Saxon Chronicle](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_Chronicle
"Anglo-Saxon Chronicle")_ or named in any surviving manuscript written between
400 and 820.[13] He is absent from [Bede](/wiki/Bede "Bede")'s early-8th-
century _[Ecclesiastical History of the English
People](/wiki/Historia_ecclesiastica_gentis_Anglorum "Historia ecclesiastica
gentis Anglorum")_ , another major early source for post-Roman history that
mentions Badon.[14] The historian David Dumville has written: "I think we can
dispose of him [Arthur] quite briefly. He owes his place in our history books
to a 'no smoke without fire' school of thought ... The fact of the matter is
that there is no historical evidence about Arthur; we must reject him from our
histories and, above all, from the titles of our books."[15]

Some scholars argue that Arthur was originally a fictional hero of folklore—or
even a half-forgotten [Celtic deity](/wiki/Celtic_mythology "Celtic
mythology")—who became credited with real deeds in the distant past. They cite
parallels with figures such as the [Kentish](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kent "Kingdom of
Kent") [Hengist and Horsa](/wiki/Hengist_and_Horsa "Hengist and Horsa"), who
may be totemic horse-gods that later became historicised. Bede ascribed to
these legendary figures a historical role in the 5th-century Anglo-Saxon
conquest of eastern Britain.[16] It is not even certain that Arthur was
considered a king in the early texts. Neither the _Historia_ nor the _Annales_
calls him "_rex_ ": the former calls him instead "_[dux](/wiki/Dux "Dux")
bellorum_" (leader of battles) and "_miles_ " (soldier).[17]

Historical documents for the post-Roman period are scarce, so a definitive
answer to the question of Arthur's historical existence is unlikely. [Sites
and places have been identified as
"Arthurian"](/wiki/Sites_and_places_associated_with_Arthurian_legend "Sites
and places associated with Arthurian legend") since the 12th century,[18] but
archaeology can confidently reveal names only through inscriptions found in
secure [contexts](/wiki/Archaeological_context "Archaeological context"). The
so-called "[Arthur stone](/wiki/Arthur_stone "Arthur stone")", discovered in
1998 among the ruins at [Tintagel Castle](/wiki/Tintagel_Castle "Tintagel
Castle") in [Cornwall](/wiki/Cornwall "Cornwall") in securely dated 6th-
century contexts, created a brief stir but proved irrelevant.[19] Other
inscriptional evidence for Arthur, including the [Glastonbury
cross](/wiki/Glastonbury_Abbey#Medieval_era "Glastonbury Abbey"), is tainted
with the suggestion of forgery.[20] Although several historical figures have
been proposed as the basis for Arthur,[21] no convincing evidence for these
identifications has emerged.

## Name

Main article: [Arthur](/wiki/Arthur "Arthur")

The origin of the Welsh name "Arthur" remains a matter of debate. Some suggest
it is derived from the Roman _[nomen gentile](/wiki/Nomen_gentile "Nomen
gentile")_ (family name) [Artorius](/wiki/Artorius "Artorius"), of obscure and
contested etymology[22] (but possibly of [Messapian](/wiki/Messapian_language
"Messapian language")[23][24][25] or [Etruscan](/wiki/Etruscan_language
"Etruscan language") origin).[26][27][28] Some scholars have suggested it is
relevant to this debate that the legendary King Arthur's name only appears as
_Arthur_ , or _Arturus_ , in early Latin Arthurian texts, never as _Artōrius_
(though it should be noted that Classical Latin Artōrius became Arturius in
some Vulgar Latin dialects). However, this may not say anything about the
origin of the name _Arthur_ , as _Artōrius_ would regularly become _Art(h)ur_
when borrowed into [Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh language").[29]

Another possibility is that it is derived from a Brittonic patronym _*Arto-
rīg-ios_ (the root of which, _*arto-rīg-_ "bear-king" is to be found in the
Old Irish personal name _Art-ri_) via a Latinized form Artōrius.[30] Less
likely is the commonly proposed derivation from Welsh _arth_ "bear" \+ (g)wr
"man" (earlier _*Arto-uiros_ in Brittonic); there are phonological
difficulties with this theory—notably that a Brittonic compound name _*Arto-
uiros_ should produce Old Welsh _*Artgur_ and Middle/Modern Welsh _*Arthwr_
and not _Arthur_ (in Welsh poetry the name is always spelled _Arthur_ and is
exclusively rhymed with words ending in _-ur_ – never words ending in _-wr_ –
which confirms that the second element cannot be _[g]wr_ "man").[31][32]

An alternative theory, which has gained only limited acceptance among
professional scholars, derives the name Arthur from [Arcturus](/wiki/Arcturus
"Arcturus"), the brightest star in the constellation
[Boötes](/wiki/Bo%C3%B6tes "Boötes"), near [Ursa Major](/wiki/Ursa_Major "Ursa
Major") or the Great Bear.[33] [Classical Latin](/wiki/Classical_Latin
"Classical Latin") _Arcturus_ would also have become _Art(h)ur_ when borrowed
into Welsh, and its brightness and position in the sky led people to regard it
as the "guardian of the bear" (which is the meaning of the name in [Ancient
Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek")) and the "leader" of the other
stars in Boötes.[34]

A similar first name is [Old Irish](/wiki/Irish_language "Irish language")
_Artúr_ , which is believed to be derived directly from an early Old Welsh or
[Cumbric](/wiki/Cumbric "Cumbric") _Artur_.[35] The earliest historically
attested bearer of the name is a son or grandson of [Áedán mac
Gabráin](/wiki/%C3%81ed%C3%A1n_mac_Gabr%C3%A1in "Áedán mac Gabráin") (d. AD
609).[36]

## Medieval literary traditions

The creator of the familiar literary persona of Arthur was [Geoffrey of
Monmouth](/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth "Geoffrey of Monmouth"), with his pseudo-
historical _[Historia Regum Britanniae](/wiki/Historia_Regum_Britanniae
"Historia Regum Britanniae")_ (_History of the Kings of Britain_), written in
the 1130s. The textual sources for Arthur are usually divided into those
written before Geoffrey's _Historia_ (known as pre-Galfridian texts, from the
Latin form of Geoffrey, _Galfridus_) and those written afterwards, which could
not avoid his influence (Galfridian, or post-Galfridian, texts).

### Pre-Galfridian traditions

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Gododdin1.jpg/170px-
Gododdin1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gododdin1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gododdin1.jpg "Enlarge")

A facsimile page of _[Y Gododdin](/wiki/Y_Gododdin "Y Gododdin")_ , one of the
most famous early Welsh texts featuring Arthur (c. 1275)

The earliest literary references to Arthur come from Welsh and Breton sources.
There have been few attempts to define the nature and character of Arthur in
the pre-[Galfridian](/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth "Geoffrey of Monmouth")
tradition as a whole, rather than in a single text or text/story-type. A 2007
academic survey that does attempt this by Thomas Green identifies three key
strands to the portrayal of Arthur in this earliest material.[37] The first is
that he was a peerless warrior who functioned as the monster-hunting protector
of Britain from all internal and external threats. Some of these are human
threats, such as the Saxons he fights in the _Historia Brittonum_ , but the
majority are supernatural, including giant [cat-monsters](/wiki/Cath_Palug
"Cath Palug"), destructive [divine boars](/wiki/Twrch_Trwyth "Twrch Trwyth"),
[dragons](/wiki/Dragons "Dragons"), [dogheads](/wiki/Cynocephaly
"Cynocephaly"), [giants](/wiki/Giant_\(mythology\) "Giant \(mythology\)"), and
[witches](/wiki/Witches "Witches").[38] The second is that the pre-Galfridian
Arthur was a figure of folklore (particularly [topographic](/wiki/Toponymy
"Toponymy") or [onomastic](/wiki/Onomastic "Onomastic") folklore) and
localised magical wonder-tales, the leader of a band of superhuman heroes who
live in the wilds of the landscape.[39] The third and final strand is that the
early Welsh Arthur had a close connection with the Welsh Otherworld
[Annwn](/wiki/Annwn "Annwn"). On the one hand, he launches assaults on
Otherworldly fortresses in search of treasure and frees their prisoners. On
the other, his warband in the earliest sources includes former pagan gods, and
his wife and his possessions are clearly Otherworldly in origin.[40]

One of the most famous Welsh poetic references to Arthur comes in the
collection of heroic death-songs known as _[Y Gododdin](/wiki/Y_Gododdin "Y
Gododdin")_ (_The Gododdin_), attributed to 6th-century poet
[Aneirin](/wiki/Aneirin "Aneirin"). One stanza praises the bravery of a
warrior who slew 300 enemies, but says that despite this, "he was no Arthur" –
that is, his feats cannot compare to the valour of Arthur.[41] _Y Gododdin_ is
known only from a 13th-century manuscript, so it is impossible to determine
whether this passage is original or a later interpolation, but John Koch's
view that the passage dates from a 7th-century or earlier version is regarded
as unproven; 9th- or 10th-century dates are often proposed for it.[42] Several
poems attributed to [Taliesin](/wiki/Taliesin "Taliesin"), a poet said to have
lived in the 6th century, also refer to Arthur, although these all probably
date from between the 8th and 12th centuries.[43] They include "Kadeir
Teyrnon" ("The Chair of the Prince"),[44] which refers to "Arthur the
Blessed"; "[Preiddeu Annwn](/wiki/Preiddeu_Annwfn "Preiddeu Annwfn")" ("The
Spoils of Annwn"),[45] which recounts an expedition of Arthur to the
Otherworld; and "Marwnat vthyr pen[dragon]" ("The Elegy of Uther
Pen[dragon]"),[46] which refers to Arthur's valour and is suggestive of a
father-son relationship for Arthur and Uther that pre-dates Geoffrey of
Monmouth.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Culhwch.jpg/250px-
Culhwch.jpg)](/wiki/File:Culhwch.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Culhwch.jpg "Enlarge")

[Culhwch](/wiki/Culhwch "Culhwch") entering Arthur's court in the Welsh tale
"[Culhwch and Olwen](/wiki/Culhwch_and_Olwen "Culhwch and Olwen")" (1881)[47]

Other early Welsh Arthurian texts include a poem found in the _[Black Book of
Carmarthen](/wiki/Black_Book_of_Carmarthen "Black Book of Carmarthen")_ , "Pa
gur yv y porthaur?" ("What man is the gatekeeper?").[48] This takes the form
of a dialogue between Arthur and the gatekeeper of a fortress he wishes to
enter, in which Arthur recounts the names and deeds of himself and his men,
notably [Cei](/wiki/Sir_Kay "Sir Kay") (Kay) and [Bedwyr](/wiki/Bedwyr
"Bedwyr") (Bedivere). The Welsh prose tale _[Culhwch and
Olwen](/wiki/Culhwch_and_Olwen "Culhwch and Olwen")_ (c. 1100), included in
the modern [Mabinogion](/wiki/Mabinogion "Mabinogion") collection, has a much
longer list of more than 200 of Arthur's men, though Cei and Bedwyr again take
a central place. The story as a whole tells of Arthur helping his kinsman
[Culhwch](/wiki/Culhwch "Culhwch") win the hand of [Olwen](/wiki/Olwen
"Olwen"), daughter of [Ysbaddaden](/wiki/Ysbaddaden "Ysbaddaden") Chief-Giant,
by completing a series of apparently impossible tasks, including the hunt for
the great semi-divine boar [Twrch Trwyth](/wiki/Twrch_Trwyth "Twrch Trwyth").
The 9th-century _Historia Brittonum_ also refers to this tale, with the boar
there named Troy(n)t.[49] Finally, Arthur is mentioned numerous times in the
_[Welsh Triads](/wiki/Welsh_Triads "Welsh Triads")_ , a collection of short
summaries of Welsh tradition and legend which are classified into groups of
three linked characters or episodes to assist recall. The later manuscripts of
the Triads are partly derivative from Geoffrey of Monmouth and later
continental traditions, but the earliest ones show no such influence and are
usually agreed to refer to pre-existing Welsh traditions. Even in these,
however, Arthur's court has started to embody legendary Britain as a whole,
with "Arthur's Court" sometimes substituted for "The Island of Britain" in the
formula "Three XXX of the Island of Britain".[50] While it is not clear from
the _Historia Brittonum_ and the _Annales Cambriae_ that Arthur was even
considered a king, by the time _Culhwch and Olwen_ and the Triads were written
he had become _Penteyrnedd yr Ynys hon_ , "Chief of the Lords of this Island",
the overlord of Wales, Cornwall and the North.[51]

In addition to these pre-Galfridian Welsh poems and tales, Arthur appears in
some other early Latin texts besides the _Historia Brittonum_ and the _Annales
Cambriae_. In particular, Arthur features in a number of well-known _vitae_
("[Lives](/wiki/Hagiography "Hagiography")") of post-Roman
[saints](/wiki/Saint "Saint"), none of which are now generally considered to
be reliable historical sources (the earliest probably dates from the 11th
century).[52] According to the _Life of Saint[Gildas](/wiki/Gildas "Gildas")_,
written in the early 12th century by [Caradoc of
Llancarfan](/wiki/Caradoc_of_Llancarfan "Caradoc of Llancarfan"), Arthur is
said to have killed Gildas' brother Hueil and to have rescued his wife
[Gwenhwyfar](/wiki/Gwenhwyfar "Gwenhwyfar") from Glastonbury.[53] In the _Life
of Saint[Cadoc](/wiki/Cadoc "Cadoc")_, written around 1100 or a little before
by Lifris of Llancarfan, the saint gives protection to a man who killed three
of Arthur's soldiers, and Arthur demands a herd of cattle as
_[wergeld](/wiki/Wergeld "Wergeld")_ for his men. Cadoc delivers them as
demanded, but when Arthur takes possession of the animals, they turn into
bundles of ferns.[54] Similar incidents are described in the medieval
biographies of [Carannog](/wiki/Carantoc "Carantoc"), [Padarn](/wiki/Padarn
"Padarn"), and Eufflam, probably written around the 12th century. A less
obviously legendary account of Arthur appears in the _[Legenda Sancti
Goeznovii](/wiki/Goeznovius "Goeznovius")_ , which is often claimed to date
from the early 11th century (although the earliest manuscript of this text
dates from the 15th century).[55] Also important are the references to Arthur
in [William of Malmesbury](/wiki/William_of_Malmesbury "William of
Malmesbury")'s _De Gestis Regum Anglorum_ and Herman's _De Miraculis Sanctae
Mariae Laudensis_ , which together provide the first certain evidence for a
belief that Arthur was not actually dead and would at some point
[return](/wiki/King_Arthur%27s_messianic_return "King Arthur's messianic
return"), a theme that is often revisited in post-Galfridian folklore.[56]

### Geoffrey of Monmouth

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Sir_Mordred_by_H._J._Ford%2C_from_King_Arthur-
_The_Tales_of_the_Round_Table_by_Andrew_Lang%2C_1902.jpg/220px-
Sir_Mordred_by_H._J._Ford%2C_from_King_Arthur-
_The_Tales_of_the_Round_Table_by_Andrew_Lang%2C_1902.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sir_Mordred_by_H._J._Ford,_from_King_Arthur-
_The_Tales_of_the_Round_Table_by_Andrew_Lang,_1902.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sir_Mordred_by_H._J._Ford,_from_King_Arthur-
_The_Tales_of_the_Round_Table_by_Andrew_Lang,_1902.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mordred](/wiki/Mordred "Mordred"), Arthur's final foe according to Geoffrey
of Monmouth, illustrated by [H. J. Ford](/wiki/Henry_Justice_Ford "Henry
Justice Ford") (1902)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/History_of_the_Kings_%28f.75.v%29_King_Arthur.jpg/220px-
History_of_the_Kings_%28f.75.v%29_King_Arthur.jpg)](/wiki/File:History_of_the_Kings_\(f.75.v\)_King_Arthur.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:History_of_the_Kings_\(f.75.v\)_King_Arthur.jpg "Enlarge")

King Arthur. A crude illustration from a 15th-century Welsh language version
of Geoffrey of Monmouth’s Historia Regum Britanniae

The first narrative account of Arthur's life is found in [Geoffrey of
Monmouth](/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth "Geoffrey of Monmouth")'s Latin work
_[Historia Regum Britanniae](/wiki/Historia_Regum_Britanniae "Historia Regum
Britanniae")_ (_History of the Kings of Britain_), completed c. 1138.[57] This
work is an imaginative and fanciful account of British kings from the
legendary Trojan exile [Brutus](/wiki/Brutus_of_Troy "Brutus of Troy") to the
7th-century Welsh king [Cadwallader](/wiki/Cadwaladr "Cadwaladr"). Geoffrey
places Arthur in the same post-Roman period as do _[Historia
Brittonum](/wiki/Historia_Brittonum "Historia Brittonum")_ and _[Annales
Cambriae](/wiki/Annales_Cambriae "Annales Cambriae")_. He incorporates
Arthur's father, [Uther Pendragon](/wiki/Uther_Pendragon "Uther Pendragon"),
his magician advisor [Merlin](/wiki/Merlin "Merlin"), and the story of
Arthur's conception, in which Uther, disguised as his enemy
[Gorlois](/wiki/Gorlois "Gorlois") by Merlin's magic, sleeps with Gorlois's
wife [Igerna](/wiki/Igraine "Igraine") at [Tintagel](/wiki/Tintagel
"Tintagel"), and she conceives Arthur. On Uther's death, the fifteen-year-old
Arthur succeeds him as King of Britain and fights a series of battles, similar
to those in the _Historia Brittonum_ , culminating in the Battle of Bath. He
then defeats the [Picts](/wiki/Pict "Pict") and [Scots](/wiki/Scoti "Scoti")
before creating an Arthurian empire through his conquests of Ireland,
[Iceland](/wiki/Iceland "Iceland") and the [Orkney
Islands](/wiki/Orkney_Islands "Orkney Islands"). After twelve years of peace,
Arthur sets out to expand his empire once more, taking control of
[Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway"), [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") and
[Gaul](/wiki/Gaul "Gaul"). Gaul is still held by the [Roman
Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") when it is conquered, and Arthur's
victory naturally leads to a further confrontation between his empire and
Rome's. Arthur and his warriors, including [Kaius](/wiki/Sir_Kay "Sir Kay")
(Kay), [Beduerus](/wiki/Bedivere "Bedivere") (Bedivere) and
[Gualguanus](/wiki/Gawain "Gawain") (Gawain), defeat the Roman emperor [Lucius
Tiberius](/wiki/Lucius_Tiberius "Lucius Tiberius") in Gaul but, as he prepares
to march on Rome, Arthur hears that his nephew [Modredus](/wiki/Mordred
"Mordred") (Mordred)—whom he had left in charge of Britain—has married his
wife [Guenhuuara](/wiki/Guinevere "Guinevere") (Guinevere) and seized the
throne. Arthur returns to Britain and defeats and kills Modredus on the river
Camblam in Cornwall, but he is mortally wounded. He hands the crown to his
kinsman [Constantine](/wiki/Constantine_III_of_Britain "Constantine III of
Britain") and is taken to the isle of [Avalon](/wiki/Avalon "Avalon") to be
healed of his wounds, never to be seen again.[58]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Merlin_%28illustration_from_middle_ages%29.jpg/220px-
Merlin_%28illustration_from_middle_ages%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Merlin_\(illustration_from_middle_ages\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Merlin_\(illustration_from_middle_ages\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Merlin](/wiki/Merlin "Merlin"), Arthur's advisor (c. 1300)[59]

How much of this narrative was Geoffrey's own invention is open to debate.
Certainly, Geoffrey seems to have made use of the list of Arthur's twelve
battles against the Saxons found in the 9th-century _Historia Brittonum_ ,
along with the battle of Camlann from the _Annales Cambriae_ and the idea that
Arthur was [still alive](/wiki/King_Arthur%27s_messianic_return "King Arthur's
messianic return").[60] Arthur's personal status as the king of all Britain
would also seem to be borrowed from pre-Galfridian tradition, being found in
_Culhwch and Olwen_ , the _[Triads](/wiki/Welsh_Triads "Welsh Triads")_ , and
the [saints' lives](/wiki/Hagiography "Hagiography").[61] Finally, Geoffrey
borrowed many of the names for Arthur's possessions, [close
family](/wiki/King_Arthur%27s_family "King Arthur's family"), and companions
from the pre-Galfridian Welsh tradition, including Kaius (Cei), Beduerus
(Bedwyr), Guenhuuara (Gwenhwyfar), Uther (Uthyr) and perhaps also Caliburnus
(Caledfwlch), the latter becoming [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") in
subsequent Arthurian tales.[62] However, while names, key events, and titles
may have been borrowed, Brynley Roberts has argued that "the Arthurian section
is Geoffrey's literary creation and it owes nothing to prior narrative."[63]
So, for instance, the Welsh Medraut is made the villainous Modredus by
Geoffrey, but there is no trace of such a negative character for this figure
in Welsh sources until the 16th century.[64] There have been relatively few
modern attempts to challenge this notion that the _Historia Regum Britanniae_
is primarily Geoffrey's own work, with scholarly opinion often echoing
[William of Newburgh](/wiki/William_of_Newburgh "William of Newburgh")'s
late-12th-century comment that Geoffrey "made up" his narrative, perhaps
through an "inordinate love of lying".[65] [Geoffrey Ashe](/wiki/Geoffrey_Ashe
"Geoffrey Ashe") is one dissenter from this view, believing that Geoffrey's
narrative is partially derived from a lost source telling of the deeds of a
5th-century British king named [Riotamus](/wiki/Riothamus "Riothamus"), this
figure being the original Arthur, although historians and Celticists have been
reluctant to follow Ashe in his conclusions.[66]

Whatever his sources may have been, the immense popularity of Geoffrey's
_Historia Regum Britanniae_ cannot be denied. Well over 200 manuscript copies
of Geoffrey's Latin work are known to have survived, and this does not include
translations into other languages.[67] Thus, for example, around 60
manuscripts are extant containing Welsh-language versions of the _Historia_ ,
the earliest of which were created in the 13th century; the old notion that
some of these Welsh versions actually underlie Geoffrey's _Historia_ ,
advanced by antiquarians such as the 18th-century Lewis Morris, has long since
been discounted in academic circles.[68] As a result of this popularity,
Geoffrey's _Historia Regum Britanniae_ was enormously influential on the later
medieval development of the Arthurian legend. While it was by no means the
only creative force behind Arthurian romance, many of its elements were
borrowed and developed (e.g., Merlin and the final fate of Arthur), and it
provided the historical framework into which the romancers' tales of magical
and wonderful adventures were inserted.[69]

### Romance traditions

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/John_william_waterhouse_tristan_and_isolde_with_the_potion.jpg/170px-
John_william_waterhouse_tristan_and_isolde_with_the_potion.jpg)](/wiki/File:John_william_waterhouse_tristan_and_isolde_with_the_potion.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:John_william_waterhouse_tristan_and_isolde_with_the_potion.jpg
"Enlarge")

During the 12th century, Arthur's character began to be marginalised by the
accretion of "Arthurian" side-stories such as that of [Tristan and
Iseult](/wiki/Tristan_and_Iseult "Tristan and Iseult"). By [John William
Waterhouse](/wiki/John_William_Waterhouse "John William Waterhouse") (1916)

The popularity of Geoffrey's _Historia_ and its other derivative works (such
as [Wace](/wiki/Wace "Wace")'s _[Roman de Brut](/wiki/Roman_de_Brut "Roman de
Brut")_) is generally agreed to be an important factor in explaining the
appearance of significant numbers of new Arthurian works in continental Europe
during the 12th and 13th centuries, particularly in France.[70] It was not,
however, the only Arthurian influence on the developing "[Matter of
Britain](/wiki/Matter_of_Britain "Matter of Britain")". There is clear
evidence that Arthur and Arthurian tales were familiar on the Continent before
Geoffrey's work became widely known (see for example, the [Modena
Archivolt](/wiki/Modena_Archivolt "Modena Archivolt")),[71] and "Celtic" names
and stories not found in Geoffrey's _Historia_ appear in the Arthurian
[romances](/wiki/Romance_\(heroic_literature\) "Romance \(heroic
literature\)").[72] From the perspective of Arthur, perhaps the most
significant effect of this great outpouring of new Arthurian story was on the
role of the king himself: much of this 12th-century and later Arthurian
literature centres less on Arthur himself than on characters such as
[Lancelot](/wiki/Lancelot "Lancelot") and [Guinevere](/wiki/Guinevere
"Guinevere"), [Percival](/wiki/Percival "Percival"), [Galahad](/wiki/Galahad
"Galahad"), [Gawain](/wiki/Gawain "Gawain"), [Ywain](/wiki/Ywain "Ywain"), and
[Tristan and Iseult](/wiki/Tristan_and_Iseult "Tristan and Iseult"). Whereas
Arthur is very much at the centre of the pre-Galfridian material and
Geoffrey's _Historia_ itself, in the romances he is rapidly sidelined.[73] His
character also alters significantly. In both the earliest materials and
Geoffrey he is a great and ferocious warrior, who laughs as he personally
slaughters witches and giants and takes a leading role in all military
campaigns,[74] whereas in the continental romances he becomes the _roi
fainéant_ , the "do-nothing king", whose "inactivity and acquiescence
constituted a central flaw in his otherwise ideal society".[75] Arthur's role
in these works is frequently that of a wise, dignified, even-tempered,
somewhat bland, and occasionally feeble monarch. So, he simply turns pale and
silent when he learns of Lancelot's affair with Guinevere in the _Mort Artu_ ,
whilst in [Chrétien de Troyes](/wiki/Chr%C3%A9tien_de_Troyes "Chrétien de
Troyes")'s _[Yvain, the Knight of the
Lion](/wiki/Yvain,_the_Knight_of_the_Lion "Yvain, the Knight of the Lion")_ ,
he is unable to stay awake after a feast and has to retire for a nap.[76]
Nonetheless, as [Norris J. Lacy](/wiki/Norris_J._Lacy "Norris J. Lacy") has
observed, whatever his faults and frailties may be in these Arthurian
romances, "his prestige is never—or almost never—compromised by his personal
weaknesses ... his authority and glory remain intact."[77]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Arthur-
Pyle_How_Arthur_drew_forth_ye_sword.JPG/170px-Arthur-
Pyle_How_Arthur_drew_forth_ye_sword.JPG)](/wiki/File:Arthur-
Pyle_How_Arthur_drew_forth_ye_sword.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Arthur-Pyle_How_Arthur_drew_forth_ye_sword.JPG "Enlarge")

The story of Arthur drawing the [sword from a
stone](/wiki/Excalibur#Excalibur_and_the_Sword_in_the_Stone "Excalibur")
appeared in [Robert de Boron](/wiki/Robert_de_Boron "Robert de Boron")'s 13th-
century _[Merlin](/wiki/Merlin#Later_adaptations_of_the_legend "Merlin")_. By
[Howard Pyle](/wiki/Howard_Pyle "Howard Pyle") (1903)[78]

Arthur and his retinue appear in some of the
_[Lais](/wiki/Lais_of_Marie_de_France "Lais of Marie de France")_ of [Marie de
France](/wiki/Marie_de_France "Marie de France"),[79] but it was the work of
another French poet, Chrétien de Troyes, that had the greatest influence with
regard to the development of Arthur's character and legend.[80] Chrétien wrote
five Arthurian romances between c. 1170 and 1190. _[Erec and
Enide](/wiki/Erec_and_Enide "Erec and Enide")_ and _[Cligès](/wiki/Clig%C3%A8s
"Cligès")_ are tales of courtly love with Arthur's court as their backdrop,
demonstrating the shift away from the heroic world of the Welsh and Galfridian
Arthur, while _Yvain, the Knight of the Lion_ , features [Yvain](/wiki/Ywain
"Ywain") and Gawain in a supernatural adventure, with Arthur very much on the
sidelines and weakened. However, the most significant for the development of
the Arthurian legend are _[Lancelot, the Knight of the
Cart](/wiki/Lancelot,_the_Knight_of_the_Cart "Lancelot, the Knight of the
Cart")_ , which introduces Lancelot and his adulterous relationship with
Arthur's queen ([Guinevere](/wiki/Guinevere "Guinevere")), extending and
popularising the recurring theme of Arthur as a [cuckold](/wiki/Cuckold
"Cuckold"), and _[Perceval, the Story of the
Grail](/wiki/Perceval,_the_Story_of_the_Grail "Perceval, the Story of the
Grail")_ , which introduces the [Holy Grail](/wiki/Holy_Grail "Holy Grail")
and the [Fisher King](/wiki/Fisher_King "Fisher King") and which again sees
Arthur having a much reduced role.[81] Chrétien was thus "instrumental both in
the elaboration of the Arthurian legend and in the establishment of the ideal
form for the diffusion of that legend",[82] and much of what came after him in
terms of the portrayal of Arthur and his world built upon the foundations he
had laid. _Perceval_ , although unfinished, was particularly popular: four
separate continuations of the poem appeared over the next half century, with
the notion of the Grail and its quest being developed by other writers such as
[Robert de Boron](/wiki/Robert_de_Boron "Robert de Boron"), a fact that helped
accelerate the decline of Arthur in continental romance.[83] Similarly,
Lancelot and his cuckolding of Arthur with Guinevere became one of the classic
motifs of the Arthurian legend, although the Lancelot of the prose _Lancelot_
(c. 1225) and later texts was a combination of Chrétien's character and that
of [Ulrich von Zatzikhoven](/wiki/Ulrich_von_Zatzikhoven "Ulrich von
Zatzikhoven")'s _[Lanzelet](/wiki/Lanzelet "Lanzelet")_.[84] Chrétien's work
even appears to feed back into Welsh Arthurian literature, with the result
that the romance Arthur began to replace the heroic, active Arthur in Welsh
literary tradition.[85] Particularly significant in this development were the
three Welsh Arthurian romances, which are closely similar to those of
Chrétien, albeit with some significant differences: _[Owain, or the Lady of
the Fountain](/wiki/Owain,_or_the_Lady_of_the_Fountain "Owain, or the Lady of
the Fountain")_ is related to Chrétien's _Yvain_ ; _[Geraint and
Enid](/wiki/Geraint_and_Enid "Geraint and Enid")_ , to _Erec and Enide_ ; and
_[Peredur son of Efrawg](/wiki/Peredur_son_of_Efrawg "Peredur son of Efrawg")_
, to _Perceval_.[86]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Holy-grail-round-
table-bnf-ms_fr-116F-f610v-15th-detail.jpg/220px-Holy-grail-round-table-bnf-
ms_fr-116F-f610v-15th-detail.jpg)](/wiki/File:Holy-grail-round-table-bnf-
ms_fr-116F-f610v-15th-detail.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Holy-grail-round-table-bnf-ms_fr-116F-f610v-15th-detail.jpg
"Enlarge")

The [Round Table](/wiki/Round_Table "Round Table") experiences a vision of the
[Holy Grail](/wiki/Holy_Grail "Holy Grail"). By [Évrard
d'Espinques](/wiki/%C3%89vrard_d%27Espinques "Évrard d'Espinques") (c.
1475)[87]

Up to c. 1210, continental Arthurian romance was expressed primarily through
poetry; after this date the tales began to be told in prose. The most
significant of these 13th-century prose romances was the [Vulgate
Cycle](/wiki/Lancelot-Grail "Lancelot-Grail") (also known as the Lancelot-
Grail Cycle), a series of five Middle French prose works written in the first
half of that century.[88] These works were the _Estoire del Saint Grail_ , the
_Estoire de Merlin_ , the _Lancelot propre_ (or Prose _Lancelot_ , which made
up half the entire Vulgate Cycle on its own), the _Queste del Saint Graal_ and
the _Mort Artu_ , which combine to form the first coherent version of the
entire Arthurian legend. The cycle continued the trend towards reducing the
role played by Arthur in his own legend, partly through the introduction of
the character of Galahad and an expansion of the role of Merlin. It also made
Mordred the result of an [incestuous
relationship](/wiki/King_Arthur%27s_family "King Arthur's family") between
Arthur and his sister and established the role of [Camelot](/wiki/Camelot
"Camelot"), first mentioned in passing in Chrétien's _Lancelot_ , as Arthur's
primary court.[89] This series of texts was quickly followed by the [Post-
Vulgate Cycle](/wiki/Post-Vulgate_Cycle "Post-Vulgate Cycle") (c. 1230–40), of
which the _Suite du Merlin_ is a part, which greatly reduced the importance of
Lancelot's affair with Guinevere but continued to sideline Arthur, and to
focus more on the Grail quest.[88] As such, Arthur became even more of a
relatively minor character in these French prose romances; in the Vulgate
itself he only figures significantly in the _Estoire de Merlin_ and the _Mort
Artu_. During this period, Arthur was made one of the [Nine
Worthies](/wiki/Nine_Worthies "Nine Worthies"), a group of three pagan, three
Jewish and three Christian exemplars of chivalry. The Worthies were first
listed in [Jacques de Longuyon](/wiki/Jacques_de_Longuyon "Jacques de
Longuyon")'s _Voeux du Paon_ in 1312, and subsequently became a common subject
in literature and art.[90]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Sir_Gawain_and_the_Green_Knight%2C_from_Pearl_Manuscript.jpg/170px-
Sir_Gawain_and_the_Green_Knight%2C_from_Pearl_Manuscript.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sir_Gawain_and_the_Green_Knight,_from_Pearl_Manuscript.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sir_Gawain_and_the_Green_Knight,_from_Pearl_Manuscript.jpg
"Enlarge")

Arthur _(top centre)_ in an illustration to "[Sir Gawain and the Green
Knight](/wiki/Sir_Gawain_and_the_Green_Knight "Sir Gawain and the Green
Knight")" (late 14th century)

The development of the medieval Arthurian cycle and the character of the
"Arthur of romance" culminated in _[Le Morte
d'Arthur](/wiki/Le_Morte_d%27Arthur "Le Morte d'Arthur")_, [Thomas
Malory](/wiki/Thomas_Malory "Thomas Malory")'s retelling of the entire legend
in a single work in English in the late 15th century. Malory based his
book—originally titled _The Whole Book of King Arthur and of His Noble Knights
of the Round Table_ —on the various previous romance versions, in particular
the Vulgate Cycle, and appears to have aimed at creating a comprehensive and
authoritative collection of Arthurian stories.[91] Perhaps as a result of
this, and the fact that _Le Morte D 'Arthur_ was one of the earliest printed
books in England, published by [William Caxton](/wiki/William_Caxton "William
Caxton") in 1485, most later Arthurian works are derivative of Malory's.[92]

## Decline, revival, and the modern legend

### Post-medieval literature

The end of the Middle Ages brought with it a waning of interest in King
Arthur. Although Malory's English version of the great French romances was
popular, there were increasing attacks upon the truthfulness of the historical
framework of the Arthurian romances – established since Geoffrey of Monmouth's
time – and thus the legitimacy of the whole [Matter of
Britain](/wiki/Matter_of_Britain "Matter of Britain"). So, for example, the
16th-century humanist scholar [Polydore Vergil](/wiki/Polydore_Vergil
"Polydore Vergil") famously rejected the claim that Arthur was the ruler of a
post-Roman empire, found throughout the post-Galfridian medieval "chronicle
tradition", to the horror of Welsh and English antiquarians.[93] Social
changes associated with the end of the medieval period and the
[Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance") also conspired to rob the
character of Arthur and his associated legend of some of their power to
enthrall audiences, with the result that 1634 saw the last printing of
Malory's _Le Morte d 'Arthur_ for nearly 200 years.[94] King Arthur and the
Arthurian legend were not entirely abandoned, but until the early 19th century
the material was taken less seriously and was often used simply as a vehicle
for allegories of 17th- and 18th-century politics.[95] Thus [Richard
Blackmore](/wiki/Richard_Blackmore "Richard Blackmore")'s epics _Prince
Arthur_ (1695) and _King Arthur_ (1697) feature Arthur as an allegory for the
struggles of [William III](/wiki/William_III_of_England "William III of
England") against [James II](/wiki/James_II_of_England "James II of
England").[95] Similarly, the most popular Arthurian tale throughout this
period seems to have been that of [Tom Thumb](/wiki/Tom_Thumb "Tom Thumb"),
which was told first through [chapbooks](/wiki/Chapbook "Chapbook") and later
through the political plays of [Henry Fielding](/wiki/Henry_Fielding "Henry
Fielding"); although the action is clearly set in Arthurian Britain, the
treatment is humorous and Arthur appears as a primarily comedic version of his
romance character.[96]

[John Dryden](/wiki/John_Dryden "John Dryden")'s [masque](/wiki/Masque
"Masque") _[King Arthur](/wiki/King_Arthur_\(opera\) "King Arthur \(opera\)")_
is still performed, largely thanks to [Henry Purcell](/wiki/Henry_Purcell
"Henry Purcell")'s music, though seldom unabridged.

### Tennyson and the revival

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Idylls_of_the_King_3.jpg/250px-
Idylls_of_the_King_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Idylls_of_the_King_3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Idylls_of_the_King_3.jpg "Enlarge")

[Gustave Doré](/wiki/Gustave_Dor%C3%A9 "Gustave Doré")'s illustration of
[Camelot](/wiki/Camelot "Camelot") for [Alfred
Tennyson](/wiki/Alfred,_Lord_Tennyson "Alfred, Lord Tennyson")'s _[Idylls of
the King](/wiki/Idylls_of_the_King "Idylls of the King")_ (1868)[97]

In the early 19th century, [medievalism](/wiki/Medievalism "Medievalism"),
[Romanticism](/wiki/Romanticism "Romanticism"), and the [Gothic
Revival](/wiki/Gothic_Revival "Gothic Revival") reawakened interest in Arthur
and the medieval romances. A new code of ethics for 19th-century gentlemen was
shaped around the [chivalric](/wiki/Chivalry "Chivalry") ideals embodied in
the "Arthur of romance". This renewed interest first made itself felt in 1816,
when Malory's _Le Morte d 'Arthur_ was reprinted for the first time since
1634.[98] Initially, the medieval Arthurian legends were of particular
interest to poets, inspiring, for example, [William
Wordsworth](/wiki/William_Wordsworth "William Wordsworth") to write "The
Egyptian Maid" (1835), an allegory of the [Holy Grail](/wiki/Holy_Grail "Holy
Grail").[99] Pre-eminent among these was [Alfred
Tennyson](/wiki/Alfred_Tennyson,_1st_Baron_Tennyson "Alfred Tennyson, 1st
Baron Tennyson"), whose first Arthurian poem "[The Lady of
Shalott](/wiki/The_Lady_of_Shalott "The Lady of Shalott")" was published in
1832.[100] Arthur himself played a minor role in some of these works,
following in the medieval romance tradition. Tennyson's Arthurian work reached
its peak of popularity with _[Idylls of the King](/wiki/Idylls_of_the_King
"Idylls of the King")_ , however, which reworked the entire narrative of
Arthur's life for the [Victorian era](/wiki/Victorian_era "Victorian era"). It
was first published in 1859 and sold 10,000 copies within the first week.[101]
In the _Idylls_ , Arthur became a symbol of ideal manhood who ultimately
failed, through human weakness, to establish a perfect kingdom on earth.[102]
Tennyson's works prompted a large number of imitators, generated considerable
public interest in the legends of Arthur and the character himself, and
brought Malory's tales to a wider audience.[103] Indeed, the first
modernisation of Malory's great compilation of Arthur's tales was published in
1862, shortly after _Idylls_ appeared, and there were six further editions and
five competitors before the century ended.[104]

This interest in the 'Arthur of romance' and his associated stories continued
through the 19th century and into the 20th, and influenced poets such as
[William Morris](/wiki/William_Morris "William Morris") and [Pre-
Raphaelite](/wiki/Pre-Raphaelite "Pre-Raphaelite") artists including [Edward
Burne-Jones](/wiki/Edward_Burne-Jones "Edward Burne-Jones").[105] Even the
humorous tale of [Tom Thumb](/wiki/Tom_Thumb "Tom Thumb"), which had been the
primary manifestation of Arthur's legend in the 18th century, was rewritten
after the publication of _Idylls_. While Tom maintained his small stature and
remained a figure of comic relief, his story now included more elements from
the medieval Arthurian romances and Arthur is treated more seriously and
historically in these new versions.[106] The revived Arthurian romance also
proved influential in the United States, with such books as Sidney Lanier's
_The Boy 's King Arthur_ (1880) reaching wide audiences and providing
inspiration for [Mark Twain](/wiki/Mark_Twain "Mark Twain")'s satiric _[A
Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's
Court](/wiki/A_Connecticut_Yankee_in_King_Arthur%27s_Court "A Connecticut
Yankee in King Arthur's Court")_ (1889).[107] Although the 'Arthur of romance'
was sometimes central to these new Arthurian works (as he was in Burne-Jones's
"The Sleep of Arthur in Avalon", 1881-1898), on other occasions he reverted to
his medieval status and is either marginalized or even missing entirely, with
[Wagner's](/wiki/Richard_Wagner "Richard Wagner") Arthurian operas providing a
notable instance of the latter.[108] Furthermore, the revival of interest in
Arthur and the Arthurian tales did not continue unabated. By the end of the
19th century, it was confined mainly to Pre-Raphaelite imitators,[109] and it
could not avoid being affected by [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War
I"), which damaged the reputation of chivalry and thus interest in its
medieval manifestations and Arthur as chivalric role model.[110] The romance
tradition did, however, remain sufficiently powerful to persuade [Thomas
Hardy](/wiki/Thomas_Hardy "Thomas Hardy"), [Laurence
Binyon](/wiki/Laurence_Binyon "Laurence Binyon") and [John
Masefield](/wiki/John_Masefield "John Masefield") to compose Arthurian
plays,[111] and [T. S. Eliot](/wiki/T._S._Eliot "T. S. Eliot") alludes to the
Arthur myth (but not Arthur) in his poem _[The Waste
Land](/wiki/The_Waste_Land "The Waste Land")_ , which mentions the [Fisher
King](/wiki/Fisher_King "Fisher King").[112]

### Modern legend

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Boys_King_Arthur_-
_N._C._Wyeth_-_p306.jpg/170px-Boys_King_Arthur_-_N._C._Wyeth_-
_p306.jpg)](/wiki/File:Boys_King_Arthur_-_N._C._Wyeth_-_p306.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Boys_King_Arthur_-_N._C._Wyeth_-_p306.jpg "Enlarge")

The combat of Arthur and [Mordred](/wiki/Mordred "Mordred"), illustrated by
[N.C. Wyeth](/wiki/N.C._Wyeth "N.C. Wyeth") for [Sidney
Lanier](/wiki/Sidney_Lanier "Sidney Lanier")'s _[The Boy's King
Arthur](/wiki/The_Boy%27s_King_Arthur "The Boy's King Arthur")_ (1922)[113]

See also: [List of works based on Arthurian
legends](/wiki/List_of_works_based_on_Arthurian_legends "List of works based
on Arthurian legends")

In the latter half of the 20th century, the influence of the romance tradition
of Arthur continued, through novels such as [T. H. White](/wiki/T._H._White
"T. H. White")'s _[The Once and Future King](/wiki/The_Once_and_Future_King
"The Once and Future King")_ (1958) and [Marion Zimmer
Bradley](/wiki/Marion_Zimmer_Bradley "Marion Zimmer Bradley")'s _[The Mists of
Avalon](/wiki/The_Mists_of_Avalon "The Mists of Avalon")_ (1982) in addition
to comic strips such as _[Prince Valiant](/wiki/Prince_Valiant "Prince
Valiant")_ (from 1937 onward).[114] Tennyson had reworked the romance tales of
Arthur to suit and comment upon the issues of his day, and the same is often
the case with modern treatments too. Bradley's tale, for example, takes a
[feminist](/wiki/Feminist "Feminist") approach to Arthur and his legend, in
contrast to the narratives of Arthur found in medieval materials,[115] and
American authors often rework the story of Arthur to be more consistent with
values such as equality and democracy.[116] The romance Arthur has become
popular in film and theatre as well. T. H. White's novel was adapted into the
[Lerner and Loewe](/wiki/Lerner_and_Loewe "Lerner and Loewe") stage musical
_[Camelot](/wiki/Camelot_\(musical\) "Camelot \(musical\)")_ (1960) and the
[Disney](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company") animated
film _[The Sword in the Stone](/wiki/The_Sword_in_the_Stone_\(film\) "The
Sword in the Stone \(film\)")_ (1963); _Camelot_ , with its focus on the love
of Lancelot and Guinevere and the cuckolding of Arthur, was itself made into a
[film of the same name](/wiki/Camelot_\(film\) "Camelot \(film\)") in 1967.
The romance tradition of Arthur is particularly evident and, according to
critics, successfully handled in [Robert Bresson](/wiki/Robert_Bresson "Robert
Bresson")'s _[Lancelot du Lac](/wiki/Lancelot_du_Lac_\(film\) "Lancelot du Lac
\(film\)")_ (1974), [Eric Rohmer](/wiki/Eric_Rohmer "Eric Rohmer")'s
_[Perceval le Gallois](/wiki/Perceval_le_Gallois "Perceval le Gallois")_
(1978) and perhaps [John Boorman](/wiki/John_Boorman "John Boorman")'s fantasy
film _[Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur_\(film\) "Excalibur \(film\)")_ (1981); it
is also the main source of the material used in the Arthurian spoof _[Monty
Python and the Holy Grail](/wiki/Monty_Python_and_the_Holy_Grail "Monty Python
and the Holy Grail")_ (1975).[117]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/The_Death_of_King_Arthur_by_John_Garrick.jpg/170px-
The_Death_of_King_Arthur_by_John_Garrick.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Death_of_King_Arthur_by_John_Garrick.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Death_of_King_Arthur_by_John_Garrick.jpg "Enlarge")

_The Death of Arthur_ , by John Garrick (1862)

Re-tellings and re-imaginings of the romance tradition are not the only
important aspect of the modern legend of King Arthur. Attempts to portray
Arthur as a genuine historical figure of c. 500, stripping away the "romance",
have also emerged. As Taylor and Brewer have noted, this return to the
medieval "chronicle tradition"' of [Geoffrey of
Monmouth](/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth "Geoffrey of Monmouth") and the
_[Historia Brittonum](/wiki/Historia_Brittonum "Historia Brittonum")_ is a
recent trend which became dominant in Arthurian literature in the years
following the outbreak of the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War
"Second World War"), when Arthur's legendary resistance to Germanic invaders
struck a chord in Britain.[118] [Clemence Dane](/wiki/Clemence_Dane "Clemence
Dane")'s series of radio plays, _The Saviours_ (1942), used a historical
Arthur to embody the spirit of heroic resistance against desperate odds, and
[Robert Sherriff's](/wiki/R._C._Sherriff "R. C. Sherriff") play _The Long
Sunset_ (1955) saw Arthur rallying Romano-British resistance against the
Germanic invaders.[119] This trend towards placing Arthur in a historical
setting is also apparent in [historical](/wiki/Historical_novel "Historical
novel") and [fantasy novels](/wiki/Fantasy_literature "Fantasy literature")
published during this period.[120] In recent years the portrayal of Arthur as
a real hero of the 5th century has also made its way into film versions of the
Arthurian legend, most notably the TV series' _[Arthur of the
Britons](/wiki/Arthur_of_the_Britons "Arthur of the Britons")_ (1972–73),
_[Merlin](/wiki/Merlin_\(2008_TV_series\) "Merlin \(2008 TV series\)")
(2008-12)_, _[The Legend of King Arthur](/wiki/The_Legend_of_King_Arthur "The
Legend of King Arthur")_ (1979), and _[Camelot](/wiki/Camelot_\(TV_series\)
"Camelot \(TV series\)")_ (2011) [121] and the feature films _[King
Arthur](/wiki/King_Arthur_\(2004_film\) "King Arthur \(2004 film\)")_ (2004),
_[The Last Legion](/wiki/The_Last_Legion "The Last Legion")_ (2007) and _[King
Arthur: Legend of the Sword](/wiki/King_Arthur:_Legend_of_the_Sword "King
Arthur: Legend of the Sword")_ (2017).[122]

Arthur has also been used as a model for modern-day behaviour. In the 1930s,
the Order of the Fellowship of the Knights of the Round Table was formed in
Britain to promote Christian ideals and Arthurian notions of medieval
chivalry.[123] In the United States, hundreds of thousands of boys and girls
joined Arthurian youth groups, such as the Knights of King Arthur, in which
Arthur and his legends were promoted as wholesome exemplars.[124] However,
Arthur's diffusion within contemporary culture goes beyond such obviously
Arthurian endeavours, with Arthurian names being regularly attached to
objects, buildings, and places. As Norris J. Lacy has observed, "The popular
notion of Arthur appears to be limited, not surprisingly, to a few motifs and
names, but there can be no doubt of the extent to which a legend born many
centuries ago is profoundly embedded in modern culture at every level."[125]
